III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & Rule 400.4127 Staff to resident ratio.
Section (1) The licensee shall develop and adhere to a written staff-to-child
Description ratio formula for direct care workers. If a child caring institution is
contracted by the department to care for youth, the facility will
follow its contracted ratio.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation An incident report by Staff 1 suggested the facility or wing was out
of ratio on 7/13/23 between 8:30 - 10:15pm.
Investigation On 7/26/23, Complainant, who is also DCWL Program Manager,
provided a partially redacted incident report. The report dated
7/13/23 authored by Vista Maria Staff 1 identified Youth A and two
other unidentified youths. The last sentence of the report
indicated “Staff 1 noticed that Unidentified Youth Z was starting to
get triggered and asked her to stay in the living area due to not
having female staff to sit outside her door per her treatment plan.”
“Not having female staff to sit outside her door per her treatment
plan” was concerning to Complainant and suggested a possible
licensing rule violation of 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
I notified Youth A’s Foster Care Worker of this investigation
assignment. She expressed no concerns about the facility.
I reviewed the facility’s history of licensing violations.
I reviewed Vista Maria’s supervision policies and found nothing
that prohibits male staff from sitting outside a youth’s door.
However, on 6/2/23, Human Resource Director emailed the
following to Vista Maria leadership clarifying specific prohibitions
for male staff:
• 1 male staff cannot be in any area with 1 youth by himself.
• 1 male staff cannot transport a youth on or off campus by
himself.
• Male staff cannot do Observations into bedrooms after bedtime
through midnight shift.
• Male staff cannot sit with a youth that is in her bedroom on 100%
observation.
• Male staff cannot monitor bathrooms during hygiene time.
• Male staff cannot be assigned as 1:1 if that youth is the only
youth on the wing.
2

Vista Maria Mental Health has a staff to resident ratio of 1:2 during
waking hours. I requested the staff schedule for the afternoon
shift on 7/13/23. On the date/time the incident report was written,
the facility was in ratio with two or more staff monitoring three
youths at all times.
Prior to receiving this complaint, I completed an unannounced visit
on 7/5/23 at 3:30pm and found the facility was within the stated
ratio of staff to youth. On 7/27/23 at 1:00pm I showed up
unannounced again and found each of the four wings were within
ratio.
I interviewed the Therapist for Youth A and Unidentified Youth Z.
She has worked at the facility for over four years. Therapist said
there is no special staff supervision plan for Youth A. On 7/13/23,
she said Youth Z was on 1:1 staff supervision. 1:1 supervision
requires a staff person to be within arm-length distance of the
youth.
I reviewed Youth Z’s intervention plan for staff dated 7/13/23. The
plan indicated when the youth is in her room, the assigned 1:1
staff should provide eyes-on monitoring and support by sitting
outside of her door with the door open.
On 7/28/23 I interviewed Staff 1 via telephone. He has worked at
the facility for four months. Staff 1 said the wing he worked on
7/13/23 was within ratio. He said he followed Vista’s policy and
the youth’s treatment plan and apologized for the incident report
being unclear. Staff 1 said there were two male staff and one
female staff assigned to monitor three youths. The female staff
stepped off the wing briefly to assist on another wing. “I felt it best
to have Unidentified Youth Z monitored in the general area
because there were no females on the wing (at that time).”
Shortly after, another female staff arrived to cover for the female
who had left. Staff 1 explained that Unidentified Youth Z’s
treatment plan indicates a female staff must sit outside of her door
when Youth Z is in her room.
Analysis There is no evidence the facility lacked a sufficient number of staff
or was out of ratio on 7/13/23.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
3

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
